title: How Do I Adjust Photos for Uncoated Paper?
content: Is there a formula to use when adjusting photos in Photoshop for uncoated paper? My issue is that I am trying to compensate so I can print on Cougar Natural Opaque. So not only do I need to adjust for uncoated paper, but what is the best way to take yellow out of an image in Photoshop to compensate for the cream colored paper?
author: tom-tom

comments.content:
Arctic Paper has a guide to uncoated paper, which i always found very useful. Have a look here:

[http://www.arcticpaper.com/en/services/Uncoated-guide/Repro-and-printing/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150313080659/http:/www.arcticpaper.com/en/services/Uncoated-guide/Repro-and-printing/ "http://www.arcticpaper.com/en/services/Uncoated-guide/Repro-and-printing/")
Talk to whoever is going to be printing the piece. A good printer should be able to suggest CMYK conversion profile setting to use for the press and paper.

James is spot on. I've always felt the best way to work is to get a good image on your calibrated equipment, which would include a profile, then as a final step, convert to the profile supplied by the printer. Sometimes testing is needed; one trick is to profile the printer's proofer, and it then becomes the printers job to match their proofs.

The easiest way to get the proper color balance is if there is a grayscale chart with (in) the image. For white, light gray, and medium gray, the amounts of red, green and blue should be about equal. Once you have the color balance corrected, then make a small change for the paper hue if you want.

There are some limitations to this -- you can't do everything with profiles. For example, you just won't get as deep a black on uncoated paper, so you can't get quite the shadow detail, and shouldn't try. We run proofs on a profiled inkjet or laser printer with the appropriate sheet type, & correct from there.

FWIW

I wouldn't go overboard adjusting yellow for a natural stock. The eye will always perceive the stock color as the relative white point, so any yellow correction to images will run the risk of actually looking too cool in context. I would talk the matter over with your printer, as has been suggested.

Or contact someone at the paper manufacturer. Undoubtedly they've run some promotional campaigns and printed specimens of Cougar Natural with four-color photography. Someone there might have suggestions on profiles or compensations. Plus they might have specimens showing the same image on white and natural, which would allow you to judge for yourself if color compensation is even really warranted.

-- Kent.
